status_message:
China declares war against pollution 

China is waging a war against pollution and fight it with the same determination the country battled poverty, as many parts of the country have been plagued by choking smog.

The government will take strong measures to prevent and control pollution with a focus on mega cities and regions with frequent occurrence of smog, Premier Li Keqiang said Wednesday at the opening of the annual session of the National People's Congress (NPC), China's top legislature.

The government will start by reducing PM10 and PM2.5 emissions, and focus on improving the industrial structure, raising energy efficiency, reducing vehicle exhaust emissions, and preventing and monitoring wind-borne dust, Li said in his report on the work of the government.

Smog is affecting larger parts of China and environmental pollution has become a major problem, which is nature's red-light warning against the model of inefficient and blind development, Li said.

A total of 50,000 small coal-fired furnaces will be shut down this year and cleaning technologies, including desulphurization, denitrification and dust removal, will be introduced at coal-burning power plants, according to the report.

Six million old high-emission vehicles will be removed from the roads, and diesel fuel for vehicles that meets fourth-stage national standards will be provided nationwide this year.

The government will also implement the clean water action plan, strengthen the protection of sources of drinking water, prevent and control water pollution in key river basins, and carry out land restoration, according to the report.

Peace can only be preserved with strength: NPC spokeswoman

A spokeswoman for China's top legislature on Tuesday defended the country's defense policies, saying that peace can only be preserved with strength.

Responding to a question concerning China's growing military power, Fu Ying, spokeswoman for the second session of the 12th National People's Congress (NPC), said China as a major power is responsible for regional peace and security.

"Based on our history and experience, we believe that peace can only be maintained by strength," she told a press conference.

China's military spending has long been cited as a cause for concern in Western countries.

"We have heard such concerns... Indeed, certain countries have been selling the idea of China as a major threat," Fu told the press conference, "but we Chinese might ask, can a prosperous country such as China really achieve peace without a strong national defense?"

The spokeswoman had made similar comments in various occasions. "It's not good news to the world that a country as large as China is unable to protect itself," earlier reports quoted Fu as saying last year.

At Tuesday's press conference, Fu said China, whose defense policy is entirely defensive in nature, has never treated any country as an enemy or a threat.

Cooperation is the main theme of China's relations with its neighboring countries, she said, adding that China has always advocated peaceful solutions to territorial and maritime disputes with other countries.

"For disputes which cannot be settled in the short term, we could always set them aside, or negotiate joint development plans," said Fu, who added that a country's military power should be viewed in terms of its future policy trends.

However, China will "respond effectively" to provocations by those ready to sabotage regional security and order "for the sake of China's own territorial sovereignty, as well as for the protection of regional order and peace," she said.

Commenting on the U.S. pivot to Asia, Fu said although the U.S. had repeatedly stress that it does not have a specific strategy to contain China and that it had not target China, "we still have to see whether its words match its deeds."

"It is my understanding that both China and the U.S. are willing to expand cooperation, and we sincerely hope that interactions between China and the U.S. in Asia are cooperation-oriented on a general term," she said.

The second session of the 12th National People's Congress will start on Wednesday.

status_message:
Kunming terror attack: International condemnation

International support of China's anti-terrorist fight continued to grow 
as more countries condemned the knife attack at a train station in southwest China city of Kunming on Saturday, which killed 29 people.

The United States on Monday called the attack "an act of terrorism" and extended its condolences for the loss of life.
   
"Based on the information reported by the Chinese media, this appears to be an act of terrorism targeting random members of the public, so we are calling this an act of terrorism," State Department Spokeswoman Jen Psaki told a press briefing.
  
The United States extends its condolences for the loss of life, said Psaki, adding that the country opposes terrorism "in all of its forms."
"We deplore violence intentionally directed at innocent civilians in any case regardless of the cause," Psaki said.
   
The Turkish Foreign Ministry also issued a statement on Monday, sharply condemning Saturday's terrorist attack at the Kunming train station and extended sympathy and condolences to the victims and their families, hoping that the wounded will recover as soon as possible.
   
Turkey said it has always stressed that terrorist attacks targeting innocent civilians is unacceptable, adding that those who are responsible for the attacks must be brought to justice.
   
South Korean Deputy Foreign Minister Lee Kyung-soo on Monday denounced the terror attack, during a meeting with Chinese ambassador Qiu Guohong.
 
On the same day, Iran slammed the terrorist attack,Press TV reported quoting Iranian Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Marzieh Afkham as saying.
"The Islamic Republic of Iran, as a victim of terrorism, expresses its opposition to terrorist acts in any forms," Afkham said.

Singaporean Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman strongly condemned the violent attacks and expressed deepest condolences to the victims and their families and wish those injured a quick recovery.

"Such attacks on innocent civilians cannot be pardoned or justified under any circumstances," said the spokesman.

President of Kazakhstan Nursultan Nazarbayev also extended his condolences on Monday in a message to his Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping, according to the country's presidential press office.
   
"I want to emphasize that there are no excuses for crimes against humanity," Nazarbayev said in his message. "The international community must work together to neutralize these threats."

At least 27 people were confirmed dead and 109 others injured in a railway station violent attack Saturday in southwest Chinese city of Kunming, authorities said.
   A group of unidentified armed people stormed into the railway station in the capital of Yunnan Province, city police said.
   Pictures on Sina Weibo, the Chinese equivalent of Twitter, show local police patrolling the station. Bodies in blood can be spotted on the ground in the pictures. Doctors were seen transporting injured people to local hospitals.
   A Weibo user screen-named "HuangY3xin-Dione," who was dining in a restaurant near the railway station, said that she was "scared to death," adding that she saw a group in black each with two long knives chasing people.

status_message:
"The lesson from the 2014 Chinese New Year holiday is to embrace this Chinese holiday and in doing so help drive New Zealand's travel, tourism and trade sectors." Auckland Airport general manager aeronautical commercial Glenn Wedlock said in a statement.

China's Lunar New Year holiday this year contributed 117 million NZ dollars (98.14 million U.S. dollars) to the New Zealand economy, according to figures from the country's main international port of entry Friday.

"This Chinese New Year saw 34,500 Chinese passengers arrive in New Zealand over the few weeks that make up this important holiday season," said Wedlock.

"With the average Chinese travelers spending 3,400 NZ dollars ( 2,852 U.S. dollars) per visit, that means around 117 million NZ dollars were spent during the Chinese New Year."

The Chinese New Year holiday period, which ran from Jan. 31 to Feb. 14 this year, was a crucial time for both the New Zealand tourism industry and the national economy, but the figures were also a warning against complacency amid growing global competition, he said.

"Already the Seychelles has introduced a visa waiver scheme and Thailand has introduced a visa on-arrival scheme to attract more Chinese travelers," said Wedlock.

status_message:
A couple of four-year-old giant pandas from a breeding center in southwest China's Sichuan Province are leaving for Belgium on Saturday, where they will stay for 15 years in the Pairi Daiza zoo of Belgium.

Xing Hui, the male and Hao Hao, the female, will stay in Belgium under the announced convention of the two countries during Belgian Prime Minister Elio Di Rupo's visit to China last year.

China Conservation and Research Center for the Giant Pandas, the world's largest scientific research organization for the rare species, confirmed with Xinhua that the panda couples were "in a good condition and ready for the trip".

"It's the first time that we lease the animal abroad for so long (15 years), and we hope they can adapt the life in Belgium as soon as possible," Zhang Hemin, head of the center told Xinhua.

The pair are expected to arrive in Brussels on Sunday by a charted DHL aircraft via Bahrain.

Two experienced vets will accompany the pandas for six months before the couple get on well with the new environment and their new keepers. 

Giant pandas are one of the world's most endangered species. About 1,600 of the animals live in the wild, mostly in the mountains of Sichuan, while more than 300 live in captivity.

Known as China's "national gem," more than 40 of the pandas on lease and their offsprings are now living in 17 zoos of 12 countries.

status_message:
A total of 25 baby hatches have been established in 10 provincial regions in China, and more will be set up in another 18 regions, the China Center for Children's Welfare and Adoption (CCCWA) told Xinhua.

A baby hatch is a safe place where people can anonymously bring infants and leave them to be found and cared for. The first baby hatch in China was founded in June 2011 in Shijiazhuang, capital city of north China's Hebei Province.

Li Bo, head of the CCCWA, said baby hatches can better protect babies after being abandoned and improve their survival rate.

However, baby hatches have faced some criticism, with some saying they have encouraged parents to dump their unwanted children, which is prohibited by Chinese law.

Dou Yupei, vice minister of civil affairs, said earlier at a press conference that the abandonment of babies is illegal and runs against moral values in China, but that establishing baby hatches is based on the respect for life and the priority of children's rights.

Their keeper said polar bears reach sexual maturity at the age of 5. However, the older bear is 10 years old, and the younger one is 9, making both "elder bachelors."

While some are fussing that a Chinese and a western festival have collided, millions of migrant workers are on coaches and trains, returning to the cities from their rural hometowns.

The traditional Lantern Festival falls on Feb. 14 this year, or Valentine's Day. Unlike their urban counterparts with hard choices to make between family and lover, the young migrants are more nonchalant.

"It's not the right time for rural young people with urban dreams to enjoy family reunions and romantic relationships," said 24-year-old tea specialist Wang Miao.

"The angel has gone back to heaven," remarked many Chinese upon learning of the death of Shirley Temple, the curly-haired child star whose smiling and dancing in 1930s films like "Bright Eyes" have lingered long in the memory.

China's coastal cities are facing the pressure of a severe labor shortage as the country's western interior catches up as a magnet for skilled workers.

  The situation came to the fore following publication of a survey on Monday showing a shortfall of 123,300 workers in Guangzhou, capital of south China's Guangdong Province.

Center, the government-led employment agency that conducted the survey.

status_message:
The Lantern Festival, which falls on the 15th day of the first month of the Chinese lunar calendar, will be doubly romantic this year as it will fall on February 14, Valentine's Day.

It is traditionally celebrated by hanging lanterns, playing games and eating sweet rice dumplings, or yuanxiao. But this year, it might also include chocolates and roses. 

The Lantern Festival was especially romantic in ancient China; a day when young women were usually allowed to go outdoors, offering opportunities to meet young men. Many legendary love stories start with an encounter on the Lantern Festival, so some people regard it as the Chinese version of Valentine's Day. 

However, it is not all about romance. Lion and dragon dances, acrobatic performances and fireworks are also features of this special day. Children try to solve puzzles that decorate the colorful lanterns, and are often rewarded with gifts if they get right answers.

Celebrations vary from place to place, but eating yuanxiao is common across the country and has passed down through the generations.

The last time the Lantern Festival coincided with Valentine's Day was in 1995, when many Chinese were still too conservative to discuss love openly. But in the past two decades, attitudes have changed. More Western festivals are becoming popular among young Chinese, and February 14 is a time of roses and chocolates, candlelit dinners and Valentine cards. 

Many people say Valentine's Day in China is too commercial: the price of flowers soars, restaurants are packed, and city center traffic comes to a standstill...It is often remarked that Valentine's Day is about money rather than romance.

However, others plan to marry on Friday, hoping to bask in the good fortune of two festivals, while some worry about how to celebrate the day, to see their family or go out with loved ones? What will the day hold for you? 

(by Yuan Quan)
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Today's China Hot News 

To find out what's happening in China, check it out on a daily basis with Xinhua.

[Crackdown on sex industry]

China has launched a three-month crackdown on organizers, operators and "protectors" of the rampant sex industry in Guangdong Province, where the city of Dongguan is located, often nicknamed as the country's "capital of sex."

Prostitution has been outlawed in China for six decades, but the underground business is still rampant in Dongguan, which is also known as one of China's major manufacturing bases. 

Due to footage of a national television revealing sexual services in Dongguan, the city rapidly hit headlines after thousands of police officers swooped on saunas, hotels, massage parlors and karaoke bars suspected of harboring prostitutes.

Dozens of entertainment venues have been closed and 67 people arrested. The high-profile campaign now involves investigating local officials for dereliction of duty and dealing with the "protective umbrella" of this illegal but lucrative industry.

As most Chinese came back to work from their weeklong Spring Festival holidays, Dongguan immediately became the hottest topic for domestic media as well as internet users.

The sharply divided reactions however came as a shock to the nation. Many expressed strong sympathy for unprotected sex workers, while sarcastic jokes and comments are being widely reposted.

The hot word "Dongguan" was even being implanted into trojan viruses on computers and scam text messages on cellphones.  

"Dad, I have been arrested in Dongguan (for prostitution). I need you to transfer 5,000 yuan to the bank account of officer X. No phone calls. Get me out first!" says one of such scam text messages. 

It remains rather unclear whether the ongoing crackdown, which is not for the first time in Dongguan, will be eventually effective. 

Follow-up reports already found out that prostitutes were still available in Dongguan but at higher prices.

The more important question concerns the livelihood of all those to-be-laid-off sex workers and the competitiveness of the city without illegal sex business, experts say.

[China slams Japan]

China slammed an application by a Japanese museum to the UNESCO for inclusion of 333 items left behind by WWII kamikaze suicide in the UN organization's Memory of the World Register.

"The application is trying to embellish the invasion history of Japanese militarism and challenge the achievements of the world anti-Fascism war and post-war international order," Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Hua Chunying said.

[Ivory-smuggling suspect arrested]

A suspected Chinese ivory smuggler was apprehended in Kenya, making it the first time for China to arrest a wildlife crime suspect overseas.

The suspect, surnamed Xue, was caught in Nairobi by Kenyan authorities and soon extradited to China. Xue is believed to have led an ivory trafficking group in Kenya, and the other two members of the group had been netted in mid January.

[More H7N9 victims expected]

China is likely to have more H7N9 bird flue cases after the number soared in early 2014 and another death report came from Anhui Province.

More than 120 human H7N9 cases have been reported this year, including around 30 deaths. Zhejiang and Guangdong are among the most-affected regions.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Taiwan official arrives in mainland for groundbreaking meeting

Wang Yu-chi (L), Taiwan's mainland affairs chief, arrived Tuesday morning in Nanjing, Jiangsu Province, for a four-day visit.

He will hold the first formal meeting with his mainland counterpart Zhang Zhijun, head of the State Council Taiwan Affairs Office, Tuesday afternoon in Nanjing.
   
Wang's visit is considered a breakthrough in cross-Strait relations on the basis of adhering to the "1992 consensus" and deepening mutual political trust.
   
Before his departure from Taoyuan Airport in Taiwan, Wang told media that he hopes to improve understanding and exchange views with his mainland counterpart.
   
Without the favorable development of cross-Strait relations since 2008, this visit would not have happened so easily, he said. "This is a hard-earned chance and I hope it will go well."
   
Wang, who leads a delegation of more than 20 people, will visit Dr. Sun Yat-sen's Mausoleum in Nanjing and deliver a speech at Nanjing University.
   
On his second stop in Shanghai, he is scheduled to meet mainland experts on Taiwan issues as well as visit Radio and Television Shanghai and a school for children of mainland-based Taiwanese business people.

status_message:
The Olympic ring malfunction during the opening ceremony in Sochi has inspired online sellers in China, who are making a killing on Taobao, the country's largest online shopping platform. 

Shoppers are placing orders for T-shirts, which have a print of four, not five, snowflake rings. The price of the t-shirts range from 20 yuan (3.27 U.S. dollars) to 60 yuan. 

Keywords "Sochi five rings" generate over 130 results on Taobao. One of the best sellers sold around 250 items in two days.

status_message:
Chinese people celebrated this year's Spring Festival holiday with less luxury and fewer fireworks following national calls to fight smog and extravagance.

Fireworks sales in Beijing slumped 37.7 percent during the seven-day holiday from a year earlier.

In Shanghai, the maximum density of PM 2.5 around the beginning of the new year went down 45 percent from last year.

Read more at http://xhne.ws/VT2HV

status_message:
Snowstorms disrupted road traffic in northern and eastern China on Wednesday, causing chaos for travelers returning to work after Spring Festival family reunions.

Snow could be as deep as 16 cm in the affected regions, said the National Meteorological Center. Dozens of highways have been closed in snow-affected regions. 

Workday will begin on Friday after the 7-day Spring Festival holiday, but the lingering snow forces many Chinese to continue their stay at home.

The blizzard brought temperatures down by as much as 18 degrees Celsius.

Read more at http://xhne.ws/5dY7D

status_message:
A passenger plane with 44 people aboard nose-dived to the ground during sliding due to a landing gear fault in central China's Zhengzhou city, airport sources said Tuesday.

   All the 37 passengers and seven crewmen were safe, authorities said.

   The home-made Xinzhou-60 plane tumbled at around 6:33 p.m. Tuesday as it was landing at the Xinzheng International Airport in Zhengzhou, capital of Henan Province.

   Flight Joy1533, operated by Joyair, was flying in from Taiyuan, capital of north China's Shanxi Province. It was to fly to Hefei in Anhui Province after the stop in Zhengzhou.

http://xhne.ws/rft0U

status_message:
China's leading breeding center for Siberian tigers has started a new round of exercises designed to train its endangered inhabitants for a return to the wild.
 
   The Spring Festival holiday which began on Jan. 31 was the right time for such training because outdoor temperatures are ideal for the survival of the species, while the two periods of heavy snow last year provided them with sufficient water and a comfortable playing ground, according to local zoologists.

   "That is why they all look more lively and robust this year," said Liu Jianfeng, an official with the park, the world's largest breeding center for Siberian tigers.

    The wildness training will mainly target two- or three-year-old cubs bred in the center and focus on making them more efficient predators.
    
    Siberian tigers are one of the world's rarest animal species and live in frigid regions. Only 300 are believed to exist in the wild, with 20 of them in northeast China.

    The country has been trying to save the species through active breeding programs.   
http://xhne.ws/5cg6a

Yingluck in Thai general election

   Thailand caretaker Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra gestures on Feb. 2 at a polling station near her residence in Bangkok, capital of Thailand.
   By 10 a.m. local time Sunday, the general election voting had been proceeding at 333 constituencies in 68 Thai provinces, while 42 constituencies in nine provinces had canceled polling, the Election Commission said.

status_message:
Tesla to spur China's electric vehicle market
by Xinhua writer Fang Dong

   With its racing body, reasonable pricing and ecological concept, Tesla's latest pure electric sports car has caught the eye of motor enthusiasts, industry insiders and environmentalists in China.
   Amid high sales expectations and cautious sizing up by Chinese automakers, there is also hope that the American upstart can bring fresh air to China's stagnant new energy vehicle sector.
   Tesla, a U.S. electric car maker established in 2003, has generated buzz in the United States by building a coast-to-coast network of charging stations for customers to charge their cars quickly during long-distance journeys.
   It sold 18,650 units of the Model S in the U.S. market last year, up 611.8 percent year on year, ranking third in electric car sales, following products from auto giants General Motors and Nissan.
   The company made its debut in China this month with the Model S at a lower-than-expected price of 734,000 yuan (121,300 U.S. dollars), almost the same as in its home country, excluding taxes and transportation costs.
   The move was expected to bring a competitive edge for Tesla to gain a foothold in the world's largest auto market and put pressure on its rivals.
   Zhang Junyi, an auto analyst with Roland Berger Strategy Consultants, said that "Tesla could be a catfish put into the sardine pool of China," stimulating domestic manufacturers to carry out development of their own high-end electric vehicle brands.
   However, Tesla's success on the other side of the Pacific is far removed from the complex competition of the Chinese market, and its high expectations in both sales and influence have yet to be proved in China.
   In 2013, vehicle sales in China totaled 21.98 million units, marking the country's fifth straight year as the world's largest auto market.
   Nevertheless, sales of new energy vehicles stood at just 17,642 units, with sales of pure electric cars even weaker, accounting for less than 0.1 percent of the country's total car sales.
   While the lackluster sales in China indicate a difficult market for Tesla, the figure also suggests the untapped potential of the emerging market and reveals there are few, if any, strong competitors that pose a threat to Tesla.
   "Actually, no automakers in China consider electric sedans for individual customers a major development strategy, not to mention as luxury cars for high-end buyers," said Zhong Shi, an auto industry analyst.
   Jia Xinguang, an industry insider, echoed Zhong's words, pointing out that market demand for electric sedans has remained weak, as few electric auto models in China can satisfy consumers and compete with conventional cars.
   Chinese electric car buyers still face difficulties in finding charging stations when their batteries run low.
   More importantly, according to Jia, price-sensitive Chinese car buyers are more inclined to choose gasoline vehicles that provide a more comfortable driving experience at the same or lower price.
   Chinese companies are therefore reluctant to spend big bucks exploiting the electric sedan market, as even the most popular domestic brands from major producers like BYD Auto, Chery and JAC Motors saw their electric car sales linger around the thousand-unit level.
   Even if homegrown manufacturers change their mind and try to catch up with their peers overseas, their technological reserves and financing mechanisms in China can't support production and promotion of cars like Tesla's, Zhong said.
   "However, the electrification of public transportation services has proved to be a growth point boosted by government policies," Jia said.
   BYD Auto, a Chinese automobile manufacturer based in southeast China's Shenzhen, has seen strong sales of electric buses and taxis, which are easily found in the city of Shenzhen and in the provinces of Shaanxi and Hunan.
   In recent years, the proportion of pure electric coaches in China's bus market has grown quickly. The figure has climbed from 2 percent in 2010 to 9.9 percent in 2012, and is expected to approach 20 percent for 2013.
   As Tesla targets high-end buyers, it is unlikely to be confronted with the harsh market facing Chinese automakers, which focus on inexpensive electric vehicles, since neither the price nor the inconvenience of charging are likely to dissuade wealthier buyers with their own villas and underground garages.
    "Headwinds will only hit when Tesla starts to expand its business to China's low-end electric sedan market," Jia said. However, there are few signs of this happening in the near future.
   China's new energy vehicle sector is just unfolding, and it still requires further policy encouragement, infrastructure and consumer recognition.
   Zhang stressed that the country's electric sedan producers are not yet mature, with a lack of technology and difficulties in application.
   In response, the central government has rolled out an array of measures, ranging from subsidies to facility construction to boost the sector.
   In 2010, China began a pilot program in five cities, including Shanghai, Shenzhen, Hangzhou, Hefei and Changchun, to encourage individuals to buy electric sedans with subsidies of up to 60,000 yuan.
   The program was upgraded in the last year with a national promotion project in 28 Chinese cities and city clusters where government subsidies will be provided for users and manufacturers from 2013 to 2015.
   The government expects both sales and production of pure electric and hybrid vehicles to reach 500,000 units by the end of 2015, but it won't be an easy task.
  For Tesla, however, official subsidies are just the icing on the cake. With possible plans to build factories and charging stations in China, the company hopes the Chinese market will account for up to 35 percent of global sales growth this year.
   In 2013, some 22,500 units of Model S were sold in the global market, according to data from Tesla.

(Photo by Yang Lei on a Tesla electric car equipped with a giant solar panel at the 2014 International Consumer Electronics Show on Jan. 8 in Las Vegas, U.S.)

status_message:
Beijing is likely to say goodbye to winter without any snow.

Meteorologists did not even forecast any precipitation in the coming week.

Traces of snow were seen in the capital's suburbs in the small hours of Saturday. It soon disappeared before sunrise. 

The city has had a warm and dry winter with no heavy rainfall for more than 100 days, resulting in a high risk of fires and poor air quality. 

Meteorologists said it could not rule out the possibility of snow as the first flakes in 2010 fell on Feb. 10.  

Read more at http://xhne.ws/YY6Kg

status_message:
"Where the family is, is where home is."

That is how Chang Yuhai, in his sixties, summed up his bittersweet journey wading through the notorious Spring Festival travel rush from Huaiyuan, a river county in east China's Anhui Province, for Shanghai.
  
As millions of migrant workers in China pour back to their rural homes for Spring Festival, a small minority swim against the tide for rare family reunions in the megacities.

Usually, these travellers are seniors and kids, and among them this year are Chang, his wife and their granddaughter.

The three are heading for Shanghai by train, where Chang's daughter and her husband have worked for more than five years. 

"It's the first time that we haven't spent New Year in our hometown, but we don't mind. The whole family being together is the meaning of the festival," said Chang.

Read more at http://xhne.ws/02FJX

status_message:
A visit to the war-linked Yasukuni shrine by the Japanese Prime Minister and his defense of the act have drawn a stinging rebuke from Chinese veterans who fought Japanese aggression seven decades ago.

Bao Honghai, a 93-year-old former soldier, still clearly remembers horrors of the month-long battle of Tai'erzhuang in 1938, when a 500-strong special squad dashed into the enemy camp, each equipped with two hand grenades and no guns, and only a dozen survived.

Shinzo Abe's Yasukuni visit has done nothing to help the war initiator gain forgiveness for its past guilt, and it has sent a very misleading message to ordinary Japanese people, especially the young generation, said 90-year-old Wen Shengming.

"Being like this, how can it win trust from other nations?" Bao questioned.

More reading at http://xhne.ws/MrD4w

Scientists announced on Saturday that a mechanical control abnormality occurred to China's lunar rover Yutu (Jade Rabbit) because of the "complicated lunar surface environment."

The news caused a splash on China's social media. More than 36,000 reposts had been generated under the "lunar rover yutu" account on Sina Weibo, a Chinese version of Twitter.

Netizens fear for the troubled rover's destiny as repairs are under way.

The problem happened just before Yutu was about to begin its second dormancy in the lunar night, during which temperature could fall below minus 180 Celsius.

See more at http://xhne.ws/Bw6Qa

status_message:
Naked Buddha sculptures cause media stir
by Zuo Wei

Two giant naked Buddha sculptures were found climbing over the roof of a hot pot restaurant in east China's city of Jinan over the weekend, amazing local residents as well as nationwide netizens.

Pictures of the bizarre statues were posted on Sunday on Sina Weibo, a Chinese tweeting service, and soon went viral.

Some Weibo users view the pair as a powerful piece of art, which was, nevertheless, believed by others as showing little respect for Buddhism.

Many netizens also noticed the sculptures allude to a well-known dish in Chinese cuisine, fo tiao qiang, which means "Buddha jumps over the wall" because of the agreeable smell.

The controversial sculptures have been taken down by Sunday night.

Local authorities said the installation and the removal were both "business practices" and have not been interfered by the local government.
(Photos available at Chinanews.com)
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Environmental activists are calling for a ban on fireworks and firecrackers, a centuries-old invention which many Chinese consider the essence of festivity during the country's Lunar New Year. 

This year's Spring Festival, the beginning of the Chinese new year, falls on Jan. 31.     

Fireworks are only allowed in designated areas and time in cities because of safety and pollution concerns. 

Beijing has said that if serious air pollution is forecast for the Lunar New Year, firework and firecracker celebrations will be banned. The city is plastered with official posters calling for a boycott of firecrackers because of air pollution concerns.

Some Chinese argue that fewer firecrackers will reduce the choking smog that has been plaguing the nation. But others say the possible ban will deprive people from having fun. 

It seems that Chinese netizens have been equally divided.

The following are some debate highlights on Sina Weibo microblogging service about the smog and the massive use of pyrotechnics during the festival.      

"It happens only once a year and how much air pollution can that lead to? Without firecrackers, there is little festivity during the Spring Festival."  -- Zimaonana      

"Celebrating the new year with firecrackers is a tradition that we should not discard. If the firecrackers are banned, our ancestors will curse us." -- Stan_Marshall      

"I totally support the banning. Flowers and greenery can also add to the festivity, and in a more environmentally-friendly way." -- MoMo

"There are so many smoking chimneys in the country. They are ignored but firecrackers are banned?" -- Paikemengzi

status_message:
Chinese authorities on Sunday issued their first policy document of 2014, underscoring the importance of rural reform.

Key points range from food security to rural environmental concerns.

The document put improving the national food security system on the top of its policy agenda for 2014 and the next few years.

The "strictest" monitoring system will be set up to enhance food safety, it said.

The country also vowed to improve rural living environment amid its rapid urbanization drive. See more points elaborated at http://xhne.ws/b7430

status_message:
A memorial opened on Sunday in China to commemorate the Korean patriot Ahn Jung Geun who killed a top Japanese official over a century ago, when his country was under the colonial rule by Japan. 

The Korean shot dead Hirobumi Ito, who had served as the prime minister of Japan four times before becoming resident-general of Korea in 1905, at a  railway station in northeast China on Oct. 26, 1909.

Ahn was arrested at the scene of shooting and secretly executed in 1910 by the Japanese government.

The memorial hall consists of exhibition rooms telling the story of Ahn's life, and shows the exact spot where the shooting took place.

"Ahn Jung Geun was not a terrorist but one who confronted colonization bravely," said Da Zhigang, director of the institute of northeast Asian studies of Heilongjiang Provincial Academy of Social Sciences.    

The memorial hall offers free admission to the public. See more at http://xhne.ws/QjCVd

Alibaba's Internet fund Yu'E Bao raised $40 billion online, latest figures from Alipay and Tianhong Fund showed.
 
Deposits were up by 35 percent compared with the end of 2013.

With a minimum threshold at one yuan ($0.16) and returns far above bank deposit rates, Yu'E Bao was an instant hit among young people after it was launched in June 2013. http://xhne.ws/JRCrQ

status_message:
Cameroonian dancer Simon Abbe and his Chinese wife, dancer Jiang Tingyu, said that, when it comes to dance, Chinese and African cultures are the most similar.
  
They told Xinhua that the slow meditative moves of Chinese tai chi can be found in most traditional Cameroonian dancing. The foot stomping, waist twisting and upper body shaking typical of Western African dance also exist in the traditional dances of China's Dai and Tibetan ethnic groups.    

Abbe and Jiang fell in love in Cameroon and now the couple are performing contemporary dance in Beijing, Yaounde and Paris. 
    
Here is their website: http://abbedance.com/

The "made-in-China" label has been shedding its cheap image and reputation for low value-added goods as China takes over the United States to become the top powerhouse in global trade.

Machinery, electrical and high-tech products continued to expand their share of total exports with their growth rates outpacing those of other major items, but China still has to make 100 million T-shirts to trade for one airplane. See more analysis at http://xhne.ws/jUYlG

status_message:
Hehe: China's online conversation ender

"Hehe" has just won the title of China's most hurtful chat phrase for 2013 in a poll created by Chinese netizens on Sina Weibo. The phrase, which represents soft laughter in Chinese, is frequently used by web users when they feel they have nothing to say or add to their online conversations.

Just as Western people might say "interesting" to avoid silence in English, Chinese netizens say "hehe" when they feel indifferent or reluctant to follow up on a conversation.

Many Chinese netizens say their feelings get hurt when they receive such a reply since it is taken as an expression of lack of interest that could easily ruin a conversation.

status_message:
Chinese to celebrate La Ba Festival

Eating a special rice congee is a tradition on the Chinese La Ba Festival, which falls on Jan. 8 this year.
In temples across China, Buddhist monks serve bowls of free La Ba congee. People believe those who eat it will be protected from harm.
The congee typically contains a minimum of eight ingredients, including rice and red beans. This year, make your own La Ba congee and find the recipe at http://xhne.ws/x94wk

Six-month-old giant panda Yuan Zai plays with her mother in her first public appearance at the Taipei Zoo on Monday.
The cub is the first baby of "Tuan Tuan" and "Yuan Yuan," who were given as a goodwill gift to Taiwan by the Chinese mainland. The combination of their names means "reunion" in Chinese.
The baby panda attracted 4,600 visitors on Monday morning.

Michael Schumacher displays his attempt at calligraphy during the 2005 Chinese Grand Prix. The banner reads "an quan (safety)."
   The retired German F1 racer turned 45 on Friday. He is in a coma at a French hospital after a skiing accident. 
   Fans in China have sent their best wishes across cyberspace to their F1 king.
   "Wake up Schumi! Give us a smile and the whole world will forgive you for your absence these days!" said Gery on Weibo, a Chinese tweeting service.
   Xinhua and other media in China have been closely following Shumacher's condition.

status_message:
by Xinhua writer Zhang Yi

   Chinese regulators lifted a ban on new stock listings as investors close the books for 2013. The resumption signaled the launch of a reform package rolled out to reignite market confidence in one of the world's worst performers.
   Five companies said on Tuesday they received the official nod to go public after initial public offerings (IPOs) in China had been frozen for more than one year. The Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.88 percent on the year's last trading day to 2115.98. The reading is 7.07 percent lower than that on the first trading day of 2013.
   The China Securities Regulatory Commission last month announced significant changes to IPO issuance, allowing underwriters and issuers themselves to have a bigger say in when companies can launch IPOs.
   The decision came about two weeks after Chinese leaders promised an economic overhaul package that gives the market a "decisive role" in allocating resources. 
   About 50 of the more than 700 companies queuing for IPO approval are expected to be listed on China's two stock exchanges by the end of January, the regulator said.

Official statistics in the world's most populous country put the number of Chinese families that lose an only child, like Sheng's, at around 76,000 every year.
    China's lawmakers this week discussed a bill on easing the one-child policy, which has been imposed for more than three decades to prevent overpopulation.
    The easing is expected to allow couples where either parent has no siblings to have two children.

The retired medical worker risked her life to give birth to Zhizhi, who weighed 1.85 kg, and Huihui, 1.45 kg, in Hefei, Anhui, suffering hemorrhages, pain and other discomforts.
    To support the newly extended family financially, Sheng, now 63, has had to resume work and travels across the country to give lectures, leaving her daughters with two baby sitters. 
    The world's oldest mother, according to the Guinness World Records, was Maria del Carmen Bousada Lara from Spain, who gave birth by cesarean section twin boys at the age of 66 years and 358 days.
    The unmarried woman received IVF treatment in America by lying that her age was 55, after being refused the procedure in Spain.

    Her daughter's photographs would reduce sentimental Sheng to tears, and for the desperate woman, the only replacement for her daughter was another child.
    Thanks to IVF therapy, Sheng had twin girls in 2010 and freed her and her husband of the loneliness.
